title: One-on-One Tech Help at Main Library
description: Looking for some basic computer or mobile device guidance? Want to learn how to access audiobooks and eBooks? Stop by at the Main Library for our drop-in hours! Drop-in sessions will be limited to 30-minutes for each patron. We can help you with: accessing library eBooks, audiobooks, and other eResources on your devices e-mail and searching the web smartphone and mobile app questions We are not able to help you with: installing advanced software programs completing online transactions for you computer hardware and technical maintenance To view all available timeslots and dates, use the following link: One-on-One Tech Help schedule. Registration is strongly encouraged but not required. If you have any questions, please contact Gina Josette Rivera by email at gjosette@cambridgema.gov

title: Gingerbread House Competition
description: LEARN MORE AND SIGN UP HERE Join us for our first-ever Gingerbread House Building Competition. Participate as a contestant or come for free as a spectator to cheer on the builders and enjoy the drink specials. A portion of ticket sales will support our community partner, Project Bread. And there will be plenty of our collaboration beer, Bread Zeppelin, a Ginger-Spiced Ale to enjoy as well. Contestants will get a base kit of building supplies (but you're free to bring any supplemental materials needed to enhance your designs). The kit includes four walls, a roof, icing, and assorted candies. You'll have an hour to build your masterpiece before the judging begins. There will be a winner chosen by our esteemed panel of judges, and one audience favorite. Test your skills, get in the holiday spirit, and support a good cause!

title: Sushi Making Cooking Class
description: With over two decades of sushi-making expertise stretching from California to Boston, Chef Harold is ready to share his knowledge with you. This sushi fundamentals class is free of gluten, nuts and dairy, and focuses on medium inside-out rolls, or uramaki, and hand rolls, or temaki. Begin the hands-on class with miso soup, then move on to mastering sushi rolling. You'll start with a shrimp tempura hand roll, then craft a delicious sweet potato hand roll. To finish, you'll learn the secrets to making a spicy tuna roll.

title: Controne Italian Food Launch Party
description: Controne Italian Food Launch Party at Lamplighter Brewing in Cambridge, MA

title: Survivor Season 49 Watch Party
description: Join us every Wednesday at Lamplighter CX for a Survivor Watch Party! Grab your friends and settle in for the most thrilling, strategic, and jaw-dropping moments of Survivor. Don't let the beers distract you from the competition - we'll also be playing survivor bingo, with the winners getting a chance to spin the prize wheel. The competition will be fierce on and off the screen. Doors open at 7 pm, with the screening starting at 8:00 pm. All seating is first come, first serve, so plan on arriving early if you have a larger group. Please note that this event is 21+ and all guests must show a valid government-issued ID upon entry to our taproom. All space and seating is first come first serve, and an RSVP here does not guarantee entry. Questions? Get in touch: events@lamplighterbrewing.com.

title: Pottery with a Purpose - Holiday Edition
description: Grab a drink and join us for this inclusive, beginner-friendly pottery workshop at Lamplighter! Holiday Edition: Add a little handmade holiday magic to your season by sculpting functional festive decor or heartfelt gifts from clay. Make ornaments, candle holders, holiday trays, mini trees, or whatever you dream up. Think cozy, joyful, messily creative energy, because the best gifts are always the ones you make yourself. You’ll learn hand-building techniques and shape your own one-of-a-kind clay cup, perfect for coffee, tea, beer or whatever warms your soul. Bonus: it's just as satisfying to drink from as it is to make! Delicious drinks available for purchase! This workshop is 21+ only.

title: Cambridge Public Library Book Club
description: Every other month, we team up with the Cambridge Public Library to highlight contemporary works from marginalized voices. All over a fresh, craft beer, of course! We’ll gather in person in our Broadway location’s back taproom for our monthly discussion. Grab a beer, cold brew, or kombucha at the front bar, then come find us in the back. The discussion is casual, and all are welcome – even if you don’t finish the book, we’d still love to have you. Copies of the book are available at the Main Library in Cambridge, at 449 Broadway. The e-book and digital audiobook can be borrowed through the Libby app. Let us know if you need help accessing the book. Please note that our taprooms are 21+ and all guests should be prepared to show a valid, current government-issued photo ID at the door. Questions? Get in touch: events@lamplighterbrewing.com

title: Queer Knitting Group
description: Queer Knitting Group at Lamplighter Brewing in Cambridge, MA

title: Pepita Lo-Fi Friday
description: Lo-Fi Fridays are here! Just like our Lo-Fi weekends but now during the work week! Stop by the “secret” back taproom of our sweet little cafe space every Friday morning for a quiet sanctuary of productivity and peace. Need a bit of quiet time? The Lamplighter + Pepita team are here to bring you a little slice of calm. From here on out, we will open the back taproom from 8am-2pm on Friday mornings for Lo Fi Fridays. Think of it as a designated calming, quiet zone just for our Pepita patrons. We’ll play chill, ambient music to set the vibe, and folks are encouraged to read, work, study, etc. with minimal talking preferred. Grab a coffee and cozy up in the back taproom at our 284 Broadway location to soak up that tranquil energy or to get a jump start on the week ahead. Your weekend brunch plans have never been more relaxing! P.S. If you’re not feeling quiet time, the front taproom will remain open as usual for normal operations.

title: Jeopardy Bar League
description: JEOPARDY! Bar League, the official bar trivia experience from America’s Favorite Quiz Show, is coming to Lamplighter!

title: Candle Making Workshop
description: Join us at the vibrant Lamplighter Brewing Co. CX Taproom in Cambridge for our Crafts & Pints Candle-Making Series—a relaxing and creative night out where you’ll pour your own soy candles and enjoy great company (and even better beer). 📍 Lamplighter CX TaproomLocation: 110 N First Street, Cambridge, MA🕕 Time: 7:00 PM – 9:00 PM💵 Price: $39 plus Eventbrite fees🎨 Theme: Crafts & Pints Series 🚫 Please note: We do not offer a one-candle option. Tickets are per person and include two candles. 🎟️ Spots are limited! Grab your tickets and join us for a cozy, crafty night at Lamplighter Brewing Co.’s CX Taproom!

title: Brewery Yoga
description: Buy your tickets on Eventbrite! Looking for some healthy weekend plans? Join us for a Sunday morning brewery yoga class at Lamplighter Brewing Co.’s Cambridge Crossing (CX) taproom. We’ll gather in the light-filled upstairs taproom for a gentle flow. Space is limited, and reservations are required. Save your spot through Eventbrite here! All yoga levels are welcome! This class is great for beginners, as well as for experienced yogis. We’ll lead you through a guided flow with a focus on stretching, breathing, and light activity – you might work up a light sweat, but nothing too strenuous. Please plan on bringing your own yoga mat. If you don’t have a mat, a large beach towel works as well. The class takes place in our upstairs taproom at Lamplighter Brewing Co.’s CX location (110 N First St, Cambridge MA). Your ticket includes full access to the yoga class as well as a beer, cold brew coffee, or kombucha. Parking: There is street parking available, or the parking garage is available for $10 with Lamplighter validation. Show your ticket to a bartender before or after class to validate! This event is 21+ and all guests must show a valid government-issued ID. Questions? Get in touch: events@lamplighterbrewing.com.

title: Hubbub Comedy
description: GRAB YOUR TICKETS HERE What’s all the hubbub at Lamplighter CX? A great line up of Boston’s best comics! Want to know their deepest secrets? Write a question at the door and they may answer it live on-stage! Join us at our Cambridge Crossing location at 110 N First St, Cambridge for unlimited laughs and flowing beer taps! We are excited to be partnering with our favorite Cambridge based comedy group, Hubbub Comedy. This night features local comics performing in an intimate setting – delivering a memorable, can’t-miss standup comedy experience. The show starts at 8pm, with doors at 7:30pm. $15 tickets online or at the door. You must be 21+ attend, all guests will be asked to show valid government ID.

title: Broadway Trivia
description: Attend one of our most beloved, longest standing brewery traditions: Trivia Tuesday! Every Tuesday swing by our Broadway taproom for our weekly trivia night. It’s free to compete, and winners get beer money. Here’s how it works: show up with your team of 2 – 6 players starting at 7:00 pm, when we’ll open the doors to the back taproom. Head down the hallway to the back, then snag a seat. All seating is first come first serve, so we recommend arriving early – there generally is a line! The game will start at 7:30 pm, and is about two hours long (with plenty of beer breaks, of course). Questions rotate every week, and cover categories ranging from history, politics, sports, movies, pop culture, music, and more. At the end of the game, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place teams will be awarded Lamplighter gift cards – good for usage in either of our taprooms and at Pepita Coffee Co. In addition to Trivia Tuesday at our Broadway taproom, we also host weekly trivia at our CX taproom. That game takes place on Monday evenings, and is also free to join for teams of 2 – 6. We’d love to see you at either or both! Hungry? Munch on our signature giant soft pretzels or some crunchy nachos, which are available Tuesday evenings only. You’re also always welcome to bring your own food or order in, ask our staff for their favorite local recommendations. See you at trivia night! You must be 21+ attend, all guests will be asked to show valid government ID. Questions? Get in touch! You can reach us at events@lamplighterbrewing.com

title: Brewery Tour & Tasting
description: Break out your notebook and freshly sharpened No. 2 pencils because we’re going back to school! We're offering brewery tours at our original 284 Broadway location on the first Saturday of every month. Space is limited, so snag your spot right here by purchasing a ticket. Our knowledgeable team will lead you on an interactive, behind-the-scenes tour of the production floor at Lamp, where you’ll learn the essentials of craft beer-making, and how it all works at our compact, Cambridge-based facility. You'll also taste your way through the brewing process, sampling three of our current favorite draft pour picks, plus a special bonus beer to start the sipping syllabus. Will you graduate top of your class? Either way, we think you’ll find your new favorite subject. Each ticket includes: 🍻One 6 oz welcome beer, plus 3 - 5 oz flight glass-sized samples 🚶🏼A 60 min guided tasting and behind-the-scenes brewery tour 📝 Beer School "quiz" and informational answer key 📚 A Lamplighter Beer School diploma :) Questions? Get in touch! events@lamplighterbrewing.com. Please note that this event is 21+ and all guests will be asked to show a valid government-issued ID. Refund Policy We understand that plans sometimes change. If you provide us with more than 24 hours' notice prior to the event start time, we will issue a full refund to your original payment method. Within 24 hours of the start time, we will offer a refund in the form of credit to be used for a future ticketed event hosted by Lamplighter, valid for 1 year. Please note that Eventbrite fees, including processing and service fees, are nonrefundable as they are charged by Eventbrite and not under the control of Lamplighter. Please request refunds through Eventbrite, on your order confirmation page.

title: Spoondrift
description: Described as “electric Americana with a psychedelic tinge”, Spoondrift has taken the Boston jam band scene by storm with their inspired and contemplative original songs, groove-based improvisation, and energetic covers. Consisting of Mike Sim (guitar, vocals), Jason Oberstein (guitar, vocals), Ian Svagdis (drums, vocals), Alex Lyons (keyboards, vocals), and Alec Hovey (electric bass, vocals), the group was formed out of their love of music and mutual respect for all who blazed the trail before them. description: GET YOUR TICKETS HERE! LGBTQ+ stand-up comedy from local queer talent, with a super sexy surprise headliner. Come find out ;) LGBTQ+ cuties do it better. Featuring Boston's hottest and most hilarious talent, Wicked Queer Stand-up Comedy combines local comedians, incredible food, and a super sexy surprise headliner. You're in for a night full of queer community and riotous laughter. Portico Brewing will be pouring beers and seltzers, serving tacos all night! Doors: 7:30PMComedy Show: 8:00 - 9:00PMHang Until Close! (at 10pm)

title: Pixel Party
description: Build a wooden model of an iconic Nintendo character! Each participant will be given a set of painted wooden blocks that correspond with their chosen character. You will then be guided step by step on how to glue the blocks together to make a wooden model of a character from the 8-bit era of gaming. All materials will be provided and no experience is necessary. Final sculptures will vary in size. The tallest is Samus (13 inches) and the shortest are Mario & Link (each 6.7 inches). If you do not finish your sculpture during the event, you are welcome to take everything you need to finish it at home. If you would like to build a character that is not listed in the dropdown menu, feel free to email robertpatricklynch@gmail.com with requests. This is an all ages event. Children under 13 should be signed up at their parent/guardian's discretion. They will need adult supervision and have the ability to sit and do a project for 1-2 hours without being disruptive.

title: Cambridge Edition Book Club
description: Please join us for our PSB Cambridge Edition Book Club, led by bookseller Wendy! We'll meet on the fourth Monday of every month at 7pm at Porter Square Books in Cambridge (1815 Mass Ave Cambridge, MA 02140). For details on this month's book pick, visit this page, and to participate in an ongoing online discussion and see what other members have to say, visit this page!

title: Giving Tuesday 2025
description: This year participate in Giving Tuesday while getting your holiday shopping done. On Tuesday, December 2, Porter Square Books will donate 10% of our in-store sales from 12PM-8PM to a number of local nonprofits working on issues important to us and our community. We know this year, for many different reasons, members of our community are having to make difficult decisions about where to spend their often increasingly limited money, wanting to support the causes that matter to them and the people in their lives that matter to them. We hope our Giving Tuesday program will make it a little easier for you by giving you a chance to do several things at once with the same spending; getting a great gift for someone you care about, supporting organizations doing great work in your community, and keeping your local fiercely independent bookstore going.

title: Matthew Pearl, author of The Award, in conversation with Kevin Birmingham
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome Matthew Pearl for the release of his novel The Award. Kevin Birmingham will join Pearl in conversation.

title: R. Michael Cassidy, author of When the Past is All Deception
description: Porter Square Books is excited to welcome R. Michael Cassidy for his novel When the Past is All Deception.

title: Sci-fi/Fantasy Book Club
description: Please join us for our newest book club: Sci-fi/Fantasy Book Club! Meetings with be led by bookseller Connor. We'll meet on the third Monday of every month at 7pm at Porter Square Books in Cambridge (1815 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02140). For details on this month's book, please visit this page!

title: City of Peace
description: Khoma and Khaliava leave Kyiv-Brotherhood Monastery and venture off into the Ukrainian countryside on this summer vacation gone wrong. What was supposed to be a peaceful journey quickly turns into a harrowing adventure as the two friends learn about life, themselves, and the Vii – a demon banished from Hell.

title: TCS presents: Brent Weinbach
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Brent Weinbach is a recipient of the Andy Kaufman Award, which recognizes innovation in stand-up comedy. He is also responsible for various internet video sensations such as Gangster Party Line, Mind Jack, Man Gives Birth, and Ultimate Drumming Technique, as well as the cult web series, Pound House. Brent has appeared on Conan, Lopez Tonight, Comedy Central (The Meltdown, @midnight, Corporate, Kroll Show, Another Period), Cartoon Network (Adventure Time, Clarence), IFC (Comedy Bang! Bang!, Garfunkel and Oates), ABC, and Adult Swim, and also toured with the Comedians of Comedy. He plays the role of Brent on the TBS show The Dress Up Gang and his stand-up special "Appealing to the Mainstream" is on Amazon Prime. His second special "Popular Culture" is on Youtube. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: TCS presents: Katie Hannigan
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum. Katie Hannigan is a stand-up comic, actor, and writer. Her stand-up has been featured on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, Comedy Central, Just For Laughs New Faces, The Late Late Show with James Corden, and MTV. Her debut album, Feeling of Emptiness, was named Ten Best of 2022 by the Interrobang. Katie is a member of SAG-AFTRA and has appeared in That Damn Michael Che on HBO, City Island, on PBS Kids, commercials for Subway, Cheez-Its, Mabelline, Home Depot, and many indie films and sketches. Katie’s writing credits include the original series Death Hacks starring Thomas Middleditch and Kristen Schaal, from Augenblick Studios. She also hosts the popular podcast Lady Journey with comedian Sarah Tollemache. The Late Late Show set: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6mdljVKvyuc t=2s Host: Zach Valencia / Feature: Janet McNamara The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows, and 20 min. before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or drink allowed**

title: Certified Fresh
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Certified Fresh, hosted by Jack Hall, takes place every Thursday and showcases a dynamic mix of Boston’s emerging talent and seasoned comedians. Whether discovering new faces or catching a set from someone on the verge of stardom, the night promises laughter from start to finish. With performances from both up-and-coming acts and Boston’s best comics, it’s the perfect way to enjoy guaranteed laughs and get a taste of the next big thing in comedy. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: Wednesday's Rising Stars
description: 2-Item Suggested Minimum.18+ w/ ID.The Comedy Studio has long been the launchpad for fresh talent, sending comedians to national stages and beyond. Now, we’re taking things to the next level! Catch a lineup of Boston’s rising stars—future headliners delivering a night of unforgettable laughs. You’ll see comics who’ve appeared on HBO, Netflix, late-night TV, and more right before they blow up. Expect edgy, off-the-wall humor, a dash of raunch with unexpected twists, and razor-sharp takes on the chaos of modern attitudes. Millennials and Gen Z love it for a reason—this is comedy that hits where it counts. You never know who may drop in. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: Red-Eye
description: Hosted at the iconic Comedy Studio, by local favorite, Kedar Kelkar, Red-Eye is your go-to late-night stand-up comedy show. The Comedy Studio is opening its doors to some midnight mayhem with hilarious comedians from around the country on it’s quest to bring back late nightlife to Harvard Square. Whether you’re a comedy aficionado, looking for a fun night out, or a regular night owl, Red-Eye promises to deliver a memorable experience, every time. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: TCS presents: Jenny Zigrino
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.She made her late night debut on Conan with Conan O’Brien and performed a total of three guest appearances. In 2023 she performed on The Late Late Show with James Corden and was met with rave reviews. She was a Just For Laugh’s New Faces in 2016 and since then has been featured on Comedy Central, MTV, HBO, Netflix is a Joke and many others. She starred in films such as Bad Santa 2 along Billy Bob Thornton and in the horror comedy Too Late in 2021. She’s headlined festivals like Moon Tower, New York Comedy Festival, and High Plains Comedy Festival. She’s written and performed several comedy specials including Comedy Central Presents the Half Hours and her latest hour special Jen-Z premiered on Comedy Central Digital in 2023. Her latest appearance on After Midnight with Taylor Tomlinson has been hailed as one of the funniest episodes yet by fans. Her most recent Don’t Tell Comedy special is out now. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: TCS presents: Sean Patton
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Sean Patton is a comedian based in New York, by way of New Orleans. He began doing stand-up in the Crescent City and has since performed in comedy clubs and festivals across the world, including The Melbourne International Comedy Festival (2011, 2018), The Glasgow Comedy fest (2016), the Dublin Comedy fest (2017), and The Edinburgh Fringe (2017, 2019). Other festivals appearances include SXSW (2016, 2017, 2018, 2022), The Moontower comedy festival (2012, 2013, 2014, 2019), Just for Laughs Chicago (2013), Just for Laughs Toronto (2013) and Just for Laughs Montreal (2008, 2010, 2012, 2016, 2018). He's performed on Comedy Central’s Live at Gotham (2009), Late Night with Jimmy Fallon (2010), Conan (2011, 2013), and Comedy Central’s The Half Hour (2013). More recently, He's been on @midnight (2014, 2015), The Meltdown with Jonah and Kumail (2015), This Is Not Happening (2015, 2017, 2019), Showtime's Live from SXSW (2017), TruTv's Comedy Knockout (2016, 2017, 2018), and This week at the Comedy Cellar (2018, 2019, 2020). In 2019 he released his second album Scuttlebutt on Helium Records. His next album King Scorpio was released on Christmas Eve 2021 and as a special on Youtube in August 2022. His special Number One streamed on peacock from 2022-2024 and is currently available on 800lb Gorilla’s YouTube page. As for acting, He's appeared on IFC'S Maron, Comedy Central's Inside Amy Schumer and TruTV's Those who can't. He stars alongside Brian Jordan Alvarez, Stephanie Koenig, Enrico Colantoni, and Carmen Christopher in in two seasons of FX’s English Teacher The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: TCS presents: Pedro Gonzalez
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Pedro Gonzalez is one of New York’s funniest comedians and the first Latino immigrant to ever perform on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert. Originally from Columbia, he came to the U.S. at 20 with no papers, no English, and no money—but somehow managed to land an American wife and become a touring comedian with a following of over 300K and across Instagram and Facebook. He now lives in New York City with his wife, daughter, and mom. His mom is helping his wife raise the baby and Pedro. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: TCS presents: Ahmed Al-kadri
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Ahmed Al-Kadri is a Yemeni-American comedian based in Los Angeles whose stand-up blends his cultural upbringing, everyday absurdities, and straight-up goofy fun. His relatable and high-energy style has taken him around the world—from America to Asia and everywhere in between. You may have seen him on the series David Diamondhands, OFTV, or in his YouTube comedy special Special Not Special. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. title: Jimmy Tingle: Humor & Hope For Humanity
description: CLICK THIS TICKET LINK:Former commentator for 60 Minutes II and three-time "Best of Boston" winner comedian Jimmy Tingle returns to the theatrical stage in 2025 with the latest version of his solo show: Jimmy Tingle: Humor and Hope for Humanity. In Humor and Hope for Humanity, Jimmy will take us on a very funny and soul-searching journey from his Boston roots as an aspiring comic and street performer to network television, Harvard, a run for political office, and up to the present 2025 moment. Jimmy will speak to the challenges of the day with comedic insight, compassion and common sense during a 90-minute, laugh filled and thought-provoking tour de ’force performance. If laughter is the best medicine, then Jimmy Tingle is the Surgeon General of American humor. Clean, funny and hopeful, Jimmy will make you laugh, think, and feel better. Just what the doctor ordered to round out 2025. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: NYE Comedy Showcase & After Party
description: Ring in the New Year with unstoppable laughter at The Comedy Studio! It's the perfect way to kick off a brand-new year! This high-energy showcase brings together some of the sharpest stand-up talent from Boston and beyond for a night packed with bold punchlines, unforgettable stories, and crowd-roaring fun. Expect a fast-paced lineup of seasoned pros and rising stars, each delivering their very best sets to keep the good vibes rolling right into midnight. Whether you’re out with friends, on a date night, or looking for an upbeat way to celebrate solo, this show guarantees a warm, hilarious, and electric atmosphere that captures everything we love about Boston comedy. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: Kaboom! Comedy and Variety
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Enjoy jaw-dropping performances, astonishing physical feats, and laugh out loud comedy- it’s a nite you won’t forget! You’ll marvel at extraordinary talents you’d expect to find in Vegas, not anywhere near here! Many seats are within an arm’s reach of these death-defying performers, but reach for them, or you could end up with an acrobat in your Scorpion bowl! Put on by globe trotting performers Alex Feldman   Colin Campbell. The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! title: TCS presents: Ted Alexandro
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.Ted Alexandro has been a comedian for twenty years. Time Out NY called Ted “One of the funniest comedians working today.” Ted has performed on David Letterman, Conan O’Brien, Jimmy Kimmel, Craig Ferguson, The View, and two half-hour specials on Comedy Central, as well as opening for Louis C.K. at Carnegie Hall. Ted has performed internationally in Jordan, Egypt, Kuwait, Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore, Jakarta, England, Holland, Israel, South Africa, and Qatar, and has been very active in the Occupy Wall Street movement and is one of the founders of Occupy Astoria Long Island City. Ted has appeared on the television shows “Oz”, “Dr. Katz”, and “Louie” as well as collaborating with Hollis James on such videos as “Kiss Our American Ass” and “Nobody’s Dummy”, which can be found on his YouTube channel. Ted and Hollis are currently creating the web series “Teacher’s Lounge.” The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

Ted has performed internationally in Jordan, Egypt, Kuwait, Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore, Jakarta, England, Holland, Israel, South Africa, and Qatar, and has been very active in the Occupy Wall Street movement and is one of the founders of Occupy Astoria Long Island City. Ted has appeared on the television shows “Oz”, “Dr. Katz”, and “Louie” as well as collaborating with Hollis James on such videos as “Kiss Our American Ass” and “Nobody’s Dummy”, which can be found on his YouTube channel. Ted and Hollis are currently creating the web series “Teacher’s Lounge.” The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

title: TCS presents: Nate Craig
description: 18+ w/ 2-Item Suggested Minimum.An internationally touring headliner, Nate Craig is a paid regular at the LA Comedy Store and NY Comedy Cellar among others. Most recently he appears in the hit Netflix movie "Old Dads". He also played Jonah Hill's brother "Phil" in the Netflix series "Maniac" and was a cast member on TruTV's "World's Dumbest". Nate's latest comedy special, "Live at The Green Mill" was executive produced by Bill Burr, and is his second standup special distributed by the All Things Comedy network. He plays a role in the last season of the animated Netflix series "F is for Family" and was featured on Season two of Comedy Central's "Roast Battle". He's also been on AXS Gotham Comedy Live, Tosh.0, Comedy Central's "Mash-up", and he wrote for 3 seasons of "Ridiculousness" on MTV. Nate has been featured at The Just for Laughs Montreal, JFL Northwest, Bridgetown, and HBO Las Vegas Comedy Festivals. He's been on "You Made it Weird" with Pete Holmes, has written for "A Prairie Home Companion" with Garrison Keillor, and was featured on the "Best of the Bob   Tom Radio Show". He headlines internationally and has multiple full length comedy albums available on iTunes and everywhere else. Host: Andrew Balestieri / Feature: Emily Ruskowski The Bar Our Bar opens 1 hour before early shows and 20 minutes before late shows. So come early and grab a drink with us! The Bar also stays open until 1 AM, so stop by after our last show of the evening! **No outside food or beverages allowed**

Inspired by fem-style, hip hop, jazz-funk, waacking, and voguing, this class is all about self-expression and empowerment. Whether you’re a seasoned dancer or stepping in for the first time, you’ll learn dynamic routines, build confidence, and leave feeling fierce. title: Worship: "The Peace (Not) Past Our Understanding"
description: Too often peace feels elusive and fragile, outside of our control, beyond our understanding. It is tempting to look for a peace we can truly know so that we can cultivate it in our lives. So what do we do when the only peace we find is one we cannot know? Sophia Doeschler preaches.

title: Worship: Christmas Play
description: Follow Mary, Joseph, and the donkey on their journey to the place where they welcome new life and light! We warmly invite you to join us for our annual Christmas Play at First Parish, produced by the RE Team and enacted by our children and teens. This year we will offer three magical advent stories, along with musical accompaniment directed by Kenneth Griffith and narration by Rob Hardies. There will be baby lambs, wise shepherds, angels, a stubborn ox, and Christmas Mice!

title: Christmas Caroling in Harvard Square
description: Serenade shoppers and strollers from the front steps of the church! Kids can pass out candy canes while we fill the air with festive song. Meet in the Meeting House at 12:00 to run through the carols, then sing out front starting around 12:30.

title: Worship "Filling the Dark with Light and Singing"
description: On the winter solstice, on the shortest and darkest day of the year, it is easy to dwell on all the things that make us fearful and and uncomfortable in the dark; so instead, let us respond with joy. Come join us for an intergenerational service to ring in the new solar year with smiles on our faces and music in our hearts. Valentin Frank preaches

title: Gallery Talk: Heinz Mack’s Light-Relief (1960)
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Join curator Lynette Roth for a close look at Heinz Mack’s Light-Relief (1960), one of the artist’s earliest experiments with light articulation. The hand-embossed aluminum sculpture serves as a cornerstone of Mack’s oeuvre and his material experimentation as a co-founder of the influential ZERO group (1957–66). Mack recently gifted the work to the Busch-Reisinger Museum. This gallery talk is part of our New on View series, highlighting recent gallery installations and presenting new insights into recent acquisitions or old favorites. Led by: Lynette Roth, Daimler Curator of the Busch-Reisinger Museum, Division of Modern and Contemporary Art

title: Harvard Art Museums at Night
description: Make your holiday season more festive at the Harvard Art Museums! Join us for an evening of art, fun, food, prizes, and more. This event is free and open to everyone. Gather with friends and mingle inside our Italian-inspired courtyard while taking in the smooth sounds from DJ C-Zone. Enjoy food and drinks for purchase, including offerings from BareWolf Brewing. Get a head start on your holiday shopping by taking advantage of a 10% discount at the museum shop. Make art in the Materials Lab, and then enter to win an original work from the Harvard Ceramics Program. Be sure to drop in on one of our Spotlight Tours throughout the evening. You can also release your inner art sleuth in a game, and you might win a prize! Don’t forget to check out our current exhibitions. Harvard Art Museums at Night takes place the last Thursday of every month (holidays permitting), from 5 to 9pm. Each night features a new mix of local talent and community partners to make this a festive occasion for all. When arriving, enter via Quincy Street. In inclement weather, please use the Prescott entrance as it provides extra shelter. Advance registration is encouraged, but walk-in visitors are always welcome. Please note that space may be limited due to capacity. Registration opens two weeks before the event. Visit the museum website for the latest visitor policies and parking information. WBUR is the media partner for Harvard Art Museums at Night. This event is part of ArtsThursdays, a university-wide initiative supported by Harvard University Committee on the Arts (HUCA).

title: Art Study Center Seminar: Versos and Marks—Exploring the Past of Artworks
description: This event requires registration; see further details below. Join curatorial assistant Casey Monahan to explore how investigating the verso (reverse side) of an artwork can sometimes help construct the history and provenance of a work. Monahan will share how details such as labels, numbers, and other elements that are normally “unseen” are essential for curators as they research and catalogue works in the collections. Free admission, but registration is required. You can register by clicking on the event on this form, beginning Tuesday, November 25. Please arrive 15 minutes before the start of the program to allow sufficient time to sign in at the Art Study Center reception desk (Level 4), and be prepared to present a photo ID. Late seating is not permitted. All coats and bags must be placed in a locker prior to entering the study room, with lockers available on the Lower Level, Level 1, and Level 4. Children age 14 and older are welcome but must be accompanied by an adult.

title: Sketching in the Galleries: Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black (Advanced Level)
description: This event requires registration; see further details below. Join us for as long as you’d like to sketch a live model in the galleries of the exhibition Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black (September 12, 2025–January 18, 2026). Taking inspiration from the themed sections of the exhibition, Brooke Stewart, lecturer at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts at Tufts University, will lead advanced-level artists through experimenting with movement and a variety of drawing techniques, such as shading, darkening, texturing, erasing, freehand drawing, and more. Feel free to bring your own sketchbook and pencils; only a limited supply of 18 × 18 clipboards, graphite pencils, and individual sheets of 11 × 17 paper will be provided. Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black celebrates the act of drawing using familiar tools—charcoal, chalk, crayon, and graphite. Each material has distinctive properties: charcoal can be intensely rich and velvety, or delicately gray and suggestive, while graphite is slippery, shiny, and easy to erase. Crayon is deeply black and waxy, whereas chalk can be crumbly and diffuse. The creative manipulations of these media—smudging, scraping, and erasing—make them versatile tools for adding intensity, depth, precision, and expression to an artist’s vision. The exhibition includes drawings by Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, Edgar Degas, Georges Seurat, John Singer Sargent, and Odilon Redon, alongside works by 20th- and 21st-century artists, such as Piet Mondrian, Lyonel Feininger, Diego Rivera, Richard Serra, John Wilson, Isabella Quintanilla, and Toyin Ojih Odutola, all of whom push their use of drawing media in new directions. Free admission, but registration is required. You can register by clicking on the event on this form, beginning on Tuesday, November 25, at 10am.

title: Coffee with Curators for Friends of the Museums: Conserving Kenneth Noland’s Karma
description: Join us for coffee and conversation with associate paintings conservator Ellen Davis. Davis will share insights into the exciting, collaborative work happening inside the Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies labs through a deep dive into the history and conservation of Kenneth Noland’s Karma (1964). This monumental painting, featuring striking blue chevrons on unpainted, unprimed cotton duck canvas, underwent its first cleaning in September 2024—remarkably, right on the Harvard Art Museums’ lawn. Learn more about this fascinating treatment process, and after the discussion, view Karma in person in Gallery 1100. Friends Circle members will receive an invitation by mail. To become a Friends Circle member, please visit our Support page. Join today to take advantage of this special opportunity!

description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Join curatorial research associate Susan Anderson to look at how artists working at the turn of the 20th century used dry media as a means towards abstraction. This talk is offered in conjunction with the special exhibition Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black, on view from September 12, 2025 to January 18, 2026. title: Art Study Center Seminar: AI at the Museums—Coin Recovery Project
description: This event requires registration; see further details below. Explore ancient coins and learn how a small team of museum staff and students is trying to harness the power of artificial intelligence to recover coins stolen in 1973. Led by: Laure Marest, Damarete Associate Curator of Ancient Coins, Division of Asian and Mediterranean Art Yifei Bao, Hao Family Intern, Division of Asian and Mediterranean Art and Digital Infrastructure and Emerging Technology Free admission, but registration is required. You can register by clicking on the event on this form, beginning Tuesday, December 2. Please arrive 15 minutes before the start of the program to allow sufficient time to sign in at the Art Study Center reception desk (Level 4), and be prepared to present a photo ID. Late seating is not permitted. All coats and bags must be placed in a locker prior to entering the study room, with lockers available on the Lower Level, Level 1, and Level 4. Children age 14 and older are welcome but must be accompanied by an adult.

title: Meet Me at the Museums: An Architectural Perspective on Edna Andrade’s Work
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Architectural drafting techniques were fundamental to Edna Andrade’s practice, and knowing that Andrade created her drawings before digital software was available makes them all the more impressive. Architect Sarah Whiting, dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Design, will give a talk about the role of drawing in architecture and design planning in the pre-digital era. Andrade’s drawings take on a different valence when seen through the lens of Dean Whiting’s work as an architect and educator. This talk is held in conjunction with the exhibition Edna Andrade: Imagination Is Never Static (August 30, 2025–January 4, 2026). Meet Me at the Museums is a series of talks given by our campus partners, lenders, and students about their perspective on works in the collections. The series widens the circle of our offerings, allowing for a richer diversity of viewpoints, surprising interdisciplinary connections and research, and unique perspectives about our collections and exhibitions. Led by: Sarah Whiting, Dean and Josep Lluís Sert Professor of Architecture

title: Second Saturdays Story Time
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Join us for Second Saturdays Story Time in the galleries, an event in partnership with librarians from Cambridge, Somerville, Watertown, and Medford. In this wonderful, art-filled experience held every second Saturday of the month, librarians will choose thematic books to share with you and yours. Please note that the selected books are geared toward children aged 3 to 7. Caregivers must be present with their children for the duration of the event. The readings are limited to 18 people and are available on a first-come, first-served basis; no registration is required. This program is organized in partnership with the Cambridge Public Library, Somerville Public Library, Watertown Public Library, and Medford Public Library.

title: Community Sketching in the Courtyard, with Life Drawing Boston
description: This event requires registration; see further details below. Come sketch with us! In conjunction with our special exhibition Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black (September 12, 2025–January 18, 2026) and in partnership with the organization Life Drawing Boston, the Harvard Art Museums invite you to a live sketching session in the Calderwood Courtyard. This all-skills-welcome event features a live model, and David London, from Life Drawing Boston, will be on hand to offer drawing tips and support. There will be three separate 30-minute sessions offered. These sessions are free, open to the public, and designed for all who want to sketch, regardless of their artistic experience. We ask that you bring your own materials. If needed, basic drawing supplies will be available. Please note our guidelines: • Only sketchpads and graphite pencils are permitted. • No pens, charcoal, pastels, ink, or paint are allowed. Please review the Harvard Art Museums Drawing Policy before attending. Free admission, but registration is required. There are three slots available for registration: Session 1: 11–11:30am Session 2: 11:45am–12:15pm Session 3: 12:30–1pm Registering for multiple sessions is allowed. You can register by clicking on the session(s) you want on this form, beginning Thursday, December 4, at 10am.

title: Encounters with Conservation
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Have you ever wondered what happens in our conservation labs? Join a member of our Straus Center staff for an informal conversation about their work treating objects in our collections. Taking place just outside the Straus Center in the Lightbox Gallery, this presentation will give you the chance to get up close and hands-on with a selection of tools and materials used by conservation staff. In this session, conservation technician Yi Bin Liang will talk about matting, framing, and housing objects. The Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies is a world leader in fine arts conservation, research, and training. The center’s laboratories are where conservation, conservation science, and curatorial practice intersect, coming together to enrich the understanding of and care for the approximately 250,000 objects in the Harvard Art Museums collections. Space is limited, and this program is available on a first-come, first-served basis; no registration is required.

title: Partners Event: Visit to a Private Collection (Off-Site)
description: This event requires registration; see further details below. Join us for a rare opportunity to visit the private home of a contemporary art collector and experience an extraordinary collection of works by American and European artists. Discover paintings, works on paper, photography, sculptures in a variety of materials, and captivating video works. Partners events are designed especially for our supporters between the ages of 21 and 45, offering gallery tours, close-looking sessions, and other special programs led by curators, fellows, and other specialists. Registration is required. If you are a current Partner or interested in the program, please contact am_partners@harvard.edu for registration details. To become a Partner, please visit our Partners Benefits page. Join today to take advantage of this special opportunity.

title: Gallery Talk: Animal Power
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Join curatorial fellow Janet O’Brien for an exploration of the diverse range of animal representations in a recent installation in our Islamic and South Asian art galleries, including their symbolic meanings and cultural significance. On view in the Islamic art gallery (2550) are a 16th-century Persian carpet, a selection of ceramic and metal sculptural objects from 13th- and 19th-century Iran, and contemporary glass birds by Turkish artist Felekşan Onar. The display in the South Asian art gallery (2590) includes a devotional painting showing animal mounts of Hindu deities, a textile featuring hybrid creatures from Hindu mythology, and a Gujarati embroidery with rainbow-colored birds. This gallery talk is part of our New on View series, highlighting recent gallery installations and presenting new insights into recent acquisitions or old favorites. Led by: Janet O’Brien, Calderwood Curatorial Fellow in South Asian and Islamic Art, Division of Asian and Mediterranean Art

title: Gallery Talk: Drawing Light in Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. The exhibition Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black highlights a wide selection of works created primarily with dark media like charcoal, chalk, and graphite. Join curatorial assistant and practicing artist Meghan Grady for a discussion that will focus on the different techniques used by artists to depict light when working with a variety of dark media. Visitors are welcome to bring their own sketchbook and draw as we talk. Please note that pencils are the only utensils allowed to be used in the galleries. Sketch, Shade, Smudge: Drawing from Gray to Black celebrates the act of drawing using familiar tools—charcoal, chalk, crayon, and graphite. Each type of material has distinctive properties: charcoal can be intensely rich and velvety, or delicately gray and suggestive, while graphite is slippery, shiny, and easy to erase. Crayon is deeply black and waxy, whereas chalk can be crumbly and diffuse. The creative manipulations of these media—smudging, scraping, and erasing—make them versatile tools for adding intensity, depth, precision, and expression to an artist’s vision. Led by: Meghan Grady, Curatorial Assistant for Special Exhibitions and Publications, Division of European and American Art

title: Exhibition Tour: Edna Andrade: Imagination Is Never Static
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Join us for an in-depth tour of our special exhibition Edna Andrade: Imagination Is Never Static (August 30, 2025–January 4, 2026), led by Mitra Abbaspour, co-curator of the exhibition. Edna Andrade: Imagination Is Never Static offers a new look at the practice of acclaimed artist and educator Edna Andrade (1917–2008). Andrade is best known for her geometric compositions, which were inspired by her interest in studying structures in nature, architecture, astronomy, mathematics, and art history, and she carried this same set of wide-ranging inspirations and inquiry to her teaching. The exhibition emphasizes the central role of drawing as well as interdisciplinary exploration in her art and in modernist movements of the 20th century. Channeling Andrade’s own multifaceted approach to art and design, Imagination Is Never Static explores the way that she used drawing as a process of experimentation.

title: Art Study Center Seminar: A Closer Look at the Forbes Pigment Collection
description: This event requires registration; see further details below. Join conservation coordinator Alison Cariens for a closer look at pigments in our famed Forbes Pigment Collection. We’ll discuss the history of the collection, the function of the materials within our conservation labs, and the significance of the collection as a “library of color.” Together, we will also delve into the story behind each featured pigment and discuss how each lends a unique window into the history of human creativity. Led by: Alison Cariens, Conservation Coordinator and Curatorial Technician for the Straus Collections, Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies Free admission, but registration is required. You can register by clicking on the event on this form, beginning on Tuesday, January 6. Please arrive 15 minutes before the start of the program to allow sufficient time to sign in at the Art Study Center reception desk (Level 4), and be prepared to present a photo ID. title: Gallery Talk: American Works of Art at the 250th
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. From late January to early July 2026, curator of American art Horace D. Ballard will lead a series of gallery talks to coincide with the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence. Each talk will closely examine a work of art that speaks to the historical, social, and political contexts that continue to shape the events and ideas of the United States within the broader context of the colonial and political framework of the Americas. This gallery talk is part of our New on View series, highlighting recent gallery installations and presenting new insights into recent acquisitions or old favorites. Led by: Horace D. Ballard, Theodore E. Stebbins, Jr., Curator of American Art, Division of European and American Art

title: Gallery Talk: Uncovering the Layered Past of a Haniwa Figure
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. If you’re in the Calderwood Courtyard, you’ll likely see a newly installed sculpture: a 6th-century terracotta sculpture from Japan’s Kofun period (c. 250–600), called a haniwa. Haniwa were created from coils and slabs of clay, shaped into figures or structures, and then placed around the outside of royal tombs. This figure underwent comprehensive analysis and treatment in preparation for its display. Join objects conservation fellow Kaela Nurmi as she shares how the conservation treatment uncovered original surfaces obscured by layers of restoration, offering insights into how the sculpture was reconstructed in the past. This gallery talk is part of our New on View series, highlighting recent gallery installations and presenting new insights into recent acquisitions or old favorites. Led by: Kaela Nurmi, Objects Conservation Fellow, Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies

Each talk will closely examine a work of art that speaks to the historical, social, and political contexts that continue to shape the events and ideas of the United States within the broader context of the colonial and political framework of the Americas. This gallery talk is part of our New on View series, highlighting recent gallery installations and presenting new insights into recent acquisitions or old favorites. Led by: Horace D. Ballard, Theodore E. Stebbins, Jr., Curator of American Art, Division of European and American Art

title: Harvard Art Museums at Night
description: Join us for an evening of art, fun, food, and more! This event is free and open to everyone. Gather with friends and mingle inside our Italian-inspired courtyard while taking in the smooth sounds from DJ C-Zone. Browse the museum shop and chat over a snack or drink for purchase from local vendors, such as BareWolf Brewing. Wander the galleries to take in our world-class art collections—over 50 galleries to explore! Be sure to drop in on one of our Spotlight Tours throughout the evening, and stop by the Materials Lab for a fun art-making activity. Win prizes and find out more about free memberships (Member Appreciation Week is just around the corner!) Don’t forget to check out our current exhibitions. Harvard Art Museums at Night takes place the last Thursday of every month (holidays permitting), from 5 to 9pm. Each night features a new mix of local talent and community partners to make this a festive occasion for all. When arriving, enter via Quincy Street. In inclement weather, please use the Prescott entrance as it provides extra shelter. Advance registration is encouraged, but walk-in visitors are always welcome. Please note that space may be limited due to capacity. Registration opens two weeks before the event. Visit the museum website for the latest visitor policies and parking information. WBUR is the media partner for Harvard Art Museums at Night. This event is part of ArtsThursdays, a university-wide initiative supported by Harvard University Committee on the Arts (HUCA).

title: Encounters with Conservation
description: This event does not require registration; see further details below. Have you ever wondered what happens in our conservation labs? Join a member of our Straus Center staff for an informal conversation about their work treating objects in our collections. Taking place just outside the Straus Center in the Lightbox Gallery, this presentation will give you the chance to get up close and hands-on with a selection of tools and materials used by conservation staff. In this session, Penley Knipe, the Philip and Lynn Straus Senior Conservator of Works on Paper and head of the Paper Lab, will talk about mending paper. The Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies is a world leader in fine arts conservation, research, and training. The center’s laboratories are where conservation, conservation science, and curatorial practice intersect, coming together to enrich the understanding of and care for the approximately 250,000 objects in the Harvard Art Museums collections. Space is limited, and this program is available on a first-come, first-served basis; no registration is required.

title: Felice Frankel at the Cambridge Public Library
description: Harvard Book Store, the Harvard University Division of Science, the Harvard Library, and the Cambridge Public Library welcome Felice Frankel—award-winning science photographer and research scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the department of Chemical Engineering—for a discussion of her first book for young adults, Phenomenal Moments: Revealing the Hidden Science Around Us. She will be joined in conversation by Melissa Franklin—the Mallinckrodt Professor of Physics and Director of Graduate Studies at Harvard University. RSVP for free to this event or choose the "Book-Included" ticket to reserve a copy of Phenomenal Moments and pick it up at the event. Felice Frankel will sign copies of her book after the presentation. Note: Books bundled with tickets may only be picked up at the venue the night of the event, and cannot be picked up in-store beforehand. Ticket holders who purchased a book-included ticket and are unable to attend the event will be able to pick up their book at Harvard Book Store up to 30 days following the event. This offer expires after 30 days. Please note we cannot guarantee signed copies will be available to ticket holders who do not attend the event.

title: Terence Keel at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Terence Keel—award-winning scholar, the founding director of the BioCritical Studies Lab, and a professor of human biology, society, and African American studies at the University of California, Los Angeles—for a discussion of his new book The Coroner's Silence: Death Records and the Hidden Victims of Police Violence. He will be joined in conversation by Zohra Ahmed—an associate professor of law at Boston University. For readers of His Name Is George Floyd and Under the Skin. A landmark investigation into forensic medicine that exposes the systematic concealment of state-sanctioned violence through death investigations Each year, police officers kill over 1,000 people they've sworn to protect and serve. While some cases, like George Floyd's and Sandra Bland's, capture national attention, most victims remain nameless, their stories untold. The Coroner's Silence reveals a disturbing truth about these cases: coroners and other death investigators are often complicit in obscuring the violent circumstances of in-custody deaths. Through rigorous research—including critical records analysis, public health studies, and interviews with victims' families—this book unmasks the systemic failures within forensic medicine. Terence Keel shows how incomplete autopsy reports, mishandled medical documents, and strategically lost evidence effectively shield law enforcement from accountability. The Coroner’s Silence uncovers how the current system of death investigation operates as a mechanism of institutional safeguarding. By highlighting the structural powerlessness of coroners and their disconnection from the communities most affected by police violence, Keel demonstrates how bureaucratic processes can render human suffering invisible. True accountability requires more than procedural reform. It demands a fundamental reimagining of how we investigate, document, and understand deaths at the hands of state institutions. title: Anthony M. Amore at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Anthony M. Amore—Director of Security and Chief Investigator at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, and the bestselling author of Stealing Rembrandts, The Art of the Con, and The Woman Who Stole Vermeer—for a discussion of his new book, The Rembrandt Heist: The Story of a Criminal Genius, a Stolen Masterpiece, and an Enigmatic Friendship. He will be joined in conversation by Kelly Horan—The Boston Globe’s deputy editor for the "Ideas" section in Globe Opinion and a member of the Globe’s editorial board. A true crime tale of unbelievable friendship, loyalty, criminal genius, and a staggeringly audacious plot to steal one of the world’s most valuable paintings—and return it. On April 14, 1975, Myles Connor, already a known art thief, entered the Boston Museum of Fine Arts in disguise along with a cohort. The pair went directly the Dutch Gallery and proceeded to remove Portrait of Elsbeth van Rijn from its place on the wall. After a brief scuffle with the guards—with Myles deterring his partner from shooting a bystander—the pair was gone, leaving behind no traceable evidence amidst the mayhem.

title: Winter Warehouse Sale Frequent Buyer Shopping
description: The Harvard Book Store Warehouse Sale features thousands of new books deeply discounted up to 40-80% off the list price. The sale features books across genres, hardcover and paperback, adult and children's literature. For fans of our used books department, a featured selection is available at the sale to browse as well. The Warehouse Sale also features other bookish merchandise including totes, stationary, and apparel. Are you a member of our free Frequent Buyer Program? If so, Friday, December 5 is just for you! Join us at our warehouse in Needham, between 4 PM and 7 PM for exclusive early access to the sale. On Saturday, December 6 and Sunday December 7, the warehouse sale will be open to all customers from 9am-7pm both days.

title: Janet Lewis Saidi and Alexandra Socarides at Harvard Book Store
description: In celebration of the 250th anniversary of Jane Austen's birth, Harvard Book Store welcomes Janet Lewis Saidi—creator of The Austen Connection, a public-humanities and journalism project that connects Austen’s literature to the pop-culture and current events of our world today—and Alexandra Socarides—Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs at Emerson College, where she is a Professor of Writing, Literature, and Publishing—for a discussion of Saidi's book Jane Austen: The Original Romance Novelist, a beautifully curated book that is both an inspiring biography and a celebration of literary brilliance. They will be joined in conversation by Deidre Lynch—Ernest Bernbaum Professor of English Literature at Harvard University. Take a trip back in time to the Regency-era life of Jane Austen, one of literature’s most beloved novelists, with this captivating exploration of her works and the timeless themes of romance, family, and society. Pocket Portraits: Jane Austen takes you through the moments of Jane Austen’s life—some well-known and some which may be unexpected. These are the moments that shaped her six published novels, which draw deeply on themes of family, agency, philosophy, and love. From excerpts of her swoon-worthy tales like Pride and Prejudice and Emma to insight into Austen’s social commentary and why her works still leave their mark on contemporary pop culture, this book paints a vivid portrait of the complicated woman behind the quill. This beautifully curated book is both an inspiring biography and a celebration of literary brilliance. Whether you’re a longtime admirer of Austen or just beginning your literary adventure, Pocket Portraits: Jane Austen will leave you fascinated, inspired, and longing for more. Janet Lewis Saidi is the creator of The Austen Connection, a public-humanities and journalism project that connects Austen’s literature to the pop-culture and current events of our world today. title: Tracy K. Smith at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Tracy K. Smith—the Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Harvard University, former Poet Laureate of the United States, and Pulitzer Prize-winning author of five poetry collections—for a discussion of her new book, Fear Less: Poetry in Perilous Times. She will be joined in conversation by Darius Atefat-Peckham—Poetry Fellow at the Michener Center for Writers and the award-winning author of Book of Kin. A Pulitzer Prize–winning poet reveals how poetry is a powerful tool of connection and understanding in a fractured world. Drawing on deep passion and personal experience, former US Poet Laureate Tracy K. Smith demystifies the art form that has too often been mischaracterized as “inaccessible,” “irrelevant,” or “intimidating.” She argues that poetry is rooted in fundamentally human qualities innate to our capacities to love, dream, question, and cultivate community. Lifting the veil on her own creative process, Smith shows us how reading and writing poetry allows us to better confront life’s many uncertainties and losses, build camaraderie with strangers, and understand ourselves more fully. In six insightful chapters, she grounds readers in the technical elements of the craft and provides close readings of the works of contemporary poets such as Joy Harjo, Danez Smith, and Francisco Márquez, alongside classic poems by Dickinson, Keats, Millay, and others. By reimaging and reexamining the age-old art form, Fear Less is a warm invitation to find meaning, consolation, and hope through poetry for poetry fans and newcomers to the art form.

title: Scott Kerman with Michael Dukakis at The Brattle Theatre
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes Scott Kerman—humor columnist for The Eagle Tribune newspaper—and Michael Dukakis—American politician who served as Governor of Massachusetts for three terms—for a discussion of Kerman's book The Duke: Weekly Conversations With The Last Honest Politician. A Political Giant And A Comedian Walk Into A Kitchen... Tickets include admission for one and one copy of The Duke pre-signed by Scott Kerman. Note: Books bundled with tickets may only be picked up at the venue the night of the event, and cannot be picked up in-store beforehand. Ticket holders who purchased a book-included ticket and are unable to attend the event will be able to pick up their book at Harvard Book Store up to 30 days following the event. This offer expires after 30 days. Please note we cannot guarantee signed copies will be available to ticket holders who do not attend the event.

title: John Fabian Witt at Harvard Book Store
description: Harvard Book Store welcomes John Fabian Witt—Allen H. Duffy Class of 1960 Professor of Law at Yale Law School and author of Lincoln’s Code, a Pulitzer Prize finalist—for a discussion of his new book, The Radical Fund: How a Band of Visionaries and a Million Dollars Upended America. He will be joined in conversation by Noah Feldman—the Arthur Kingsley Porter University Professor at Harvard and a leading public intellectual who has authored ten critically acclaimed books. From Pulitzer Prize finalist John Fabian Witt comes the captivating secret history of an epic experiment to remake American democracy. Before the dark money of the Koch Brothers, before the billions of the Ford Foundation, there was the Garland Fund. In 1922, a young idealist named Charles Garland rejected a million-dollar inheritance. In a world of shocking wealth disparities, shameless racism, and political repression, Garland opted instead to invest in a future where radical ideas—like working-class power, free speech, and equality—might flourish. Over the next two decades, the Garland Fund would nurture a new generation of wildly ambi­tious progressive projects.

title: Swing Boot Camp – Dec 7
description: Have you ever wanted to learn to Lindy Hop but don’t have time to commit to a weekly class? This is your chance! Our next weekend “crash course” workshop is 2.5 hours, Sundays, Noon-2:20pm. Come learn from experienced teachers who are also social dancers in the Lindy Hop scene. We will cover six count basic (East Coast Swing), basic eight count (Lindy Hop), and Charleston Basic. Moves include swing out, Lindy circle, swing out from closed, and side by side Charleston. At the end of this class, you will be able to attend a social dance and dance to music.
